page.title: 01The Adur Valley - Henfield
page.content: { Landscape}is dominated by the upper reaches of the{River Adur,}its tribu- tory streams and its flood plain. The land rolls gently upwards to the ridge on which the village of Henfield is set, to the South. Its character is largely determined by the nature of farming which it supports. The land is principally{agricultural,}both arable and pastural, with a liberal sprinkling of shaws (small woodlands originally planted as cover for game birds). Population is relatively sparse, distributed in the scattered farms, farm cottages, and a group of houses and bungalows along the Horsham - Henfield road which forms part of the hamlet of Shermanbury.
